Challenging the pawn that blocks that a1-h8 diagonal.
This reverse-Slav idea would be stronger if the b-pawn was still at b2. Now there's no good square for the QB.
Piling on the pressure at d4.
He should still fianchetto the QB. It's no use at d2.
More indirect pressure on d4.
? This loses a pawn immediately and a rook eventually. Better was 9. h3, forcing black to retreat or exchange at f3. White's position would be highly playable after 9. Be2 as well.
Alternatives? Maybe 11. Be2, Nxe2+, 12. Qxe2, Nd7, 13. Bc3, Bxc3, 14. Nxc3, Ne5, 15. Qe4, Bxf3, 16. gxf3, Qd7. Black threatens ...Qh3 and ...Nxf3+, etc.

Black is a pawn up and white's K-side is destroyed. Oh, and the QR is seriously in danger. In view of all this, 13. Nc3 was necessary, albeit inadequate.
